message.raw:
Use a multiple-of-four number of samples per chan to test digital ports, as some
models (observed with PCI 6534) require this.

Use a whole digital port instead of just one line, as some
models (also PCI 6534) require this. Catch errors about requiring multiple ports
at a time for 653x models, and return True since these models do support
buffered output despite these other requirements.

The devices that require the number of samples per channel to be a multiple of
four may be a problem in labscript, since labscript does not know or care about
such requirements presently.

message.raw:
Work around the "digital outputs all being zero crashes DAQmx" issue differently
by running DO as static if DOs are all zero. This removes the requirement to
have dummy DO just to avoid this issue, including in connecition tables where
usually there are no user-given instructions.

The downside to this is the beginning of output will not be in-time with the
pseudoclock, instead it will be in software time beforehand.
Some other devices are implemented this way too though, so perhaps we are not
making any guarantees about this in any case.

message.raw:
Fix bug in which the acquisition worker's transition_to_manual method would deadlock
waiting for the wait durations to be processed, because the wait monitor worker
would not even run its transition_to_manual method until after the acquisition
worker had finished transitioning to manual.

message.raw:
Always write using WriteDigitalU32 regardless of port size.
This works around both a bug in WriteDigitalLines, see:
  #!/labscript_suite/labscript_devices/pull-requests/56/#comment-83671312
as well as a bug where with some boards smaller integer write methods throw an
error even though they are the correct size for the port, see here:
 https://forums.ni.com/t5/Multifunction-DAQ/problem-with-correlated-DIO-on-USB-6341/td-p/3344066

if the first one it tried did not support being used as an external clock.

capabiltiies of NI-PXIe_6535 resulting from the bug.

Check PyDAQmx > 1.4.1, since earlier versions raise an error when DAQmx
calls return a positive integer, but actually this is how some functions
work when you pass them a null pointer to tell you how large a buffer
they need to return the actual result. We use these functions a few times.

message.raw:
Fix more bugs in wait monitor implementation. Current problem is the range
of measurable pulses of a given device. Some cannot measure small pulses.
This would be fine if we were doing period measurement, but we are doing
semiperiod measurement...We don't actually care about the falling edges,
but the incomplete sample detection means we can't just measure rising edges
otherwise we won't know when we are at the start of the experiment and thus
can't compute a timeout time for the first wait. This is a major inconvenience!

otherwise we won't know when we are at the start of the experiment and thus
can't compute a timeout time for the first wait. This is a major inconvenience!

values.message:
Fix more bugs in wait monitor implementation. Current problem is the range
of measurable pulses of a given device. Some cannot measure small pulses.
This would be fine if we were doing period measurement, but we are doing
semiperiod measurement...We don't actually care about the falling edges,
but the incomplete sample detection means we can't just measure rising edges
otherwise we won't know when we are at the start of the experiment and thus
can't compute a timeout time for the first wait. This is a major inconvenience!

message.raw:
hacking on wait monitor. Not yet functional, some issues to iron out with
incomplete sample detection and small buffers.

Plan is to

* acquire pulse width instead of semiperiod, this will entail
only one read event per pulse rather than two, solving the issue of data
coming faster than it can be read and filling the buffer. Or maybe we will
still do semiperiod, but will read 2 samples at a time as David Meyer has had
sucess with. The advantage of this latter approach is that we do not need to
store the pulse duration in the h5 file in order to take it into account -
we can measure it.

* Determine whether a device has incomplete sample detection empirically.
  In get_capabilities.py we can create a task that outputs on a DO and reads in
  a counter, and we can see what we get and store whether it looks like
  incomplete sample detection. This should be achievable without asking the user
  to connect back any cables physically, as we should be able to configure
  them to be connected internally. This will not work if there are any devices
  out there with counters but no digital outs!

message.raw:
Add stop_acqusition_timeout and exception_on_failed_shot device properties.
This allows waiting more time for acqusition to end in the case of slow download,
and continuing without error if not all images were acquired in a shot.

(it seems that in many common configurations, shots fail, for inexplicable
reasons that might be to do with network traffic hiccups or who know what.
Users tend to want other shots to continue).

Well formatted docstring for device class.

These changes require testing.

message.raw:
make IMAQdxCamera friendier to subclassing. Fixes issue #34

Renamed `imaqdx_attributes` to just `camera_attributes`. No backward
compatibility provided for this, since this class is fairly new.

Allow specifying worker class and camera interface class as class attributes,
in the case that the subclass simply changes these and nothing else about
worker class creation, or about the instantiation of the interface class.

Remove IMAQdx specific code from worker class, into interface class.

message.raw:
Resolve issue #33.

Pulseblasters now have a long delay time computed from their core clock freq,
which has been added as an instance attribute to every subclass.
(this is messy, as it is duplicated in the BLACS worker classes too. It should be
passed as a connection table property ideally, but this will have to wait for a
more general 'pulseblaster unification' change I think, along the lines of the
NI DAQ unification).

For each clock tick, the high time is half the clock period if
`pulse_width='symmetric'` (the default), the minimum possible if
`pulse_width='minimum'`, or a fixed value if `pulse_width` is given as a number.

The high time is then clipped to self.long_delay if it is larger, in which case
the pulse_width argument is not honoured, but 57 second high times ought to be
visible on scopes and not too fast for any devices, so this is preferable to
the alternative of adding LONG_DELAY instructions to *both* the high and low
times of the clock ticks.

The low time is then computed as whatever is left, and split into a LONG_DELAY
instruction plus the remainder as an END_LOOP instruction, as before.

If the PulseBlaster has no external clocks for this clock tick, it uses a
LONG_DELAY plus the remainder as a CONTINUE instruction, as before.

times with identical name and frame type.
* Set default frame_type='frame'.
* Add mock camera class, for testing without an actual camera present.
* Fix bug in continuous acquisition
* Fix bug whereby images were not correctly matched to frames in the case of
  labscript expose() functions being called out-of-order with respect to the
  time of each frame.
*

message.raw:
Use a dedicated zmq socket for sending image data from worker to parent
rather than using state machine work requests for every frame. Otherwise the GUI
flickers with state changes for every frame, more CPU is consumed per frame,
and the data is serialised using pickle, which is less efficient that using
numpy buffers. This all wastes CPU, limits frame rate, and looks ugly.

This requires some care since the receiving thread must be cleaned up when the
tab restarts. Therefore the tab restart() method is overridden to shutdown the
corresponding ZMQserver.
